That's what I like about their never-frozen, their fresh when they come, they feel like

Preferences all ready-to-eat in two minutes.

You won't be disappointed.
Hello America and happy Wednesday of busy news Wednesday.
It is today.
Some news out of New York, the efforts to watch legal attacks against President Trump and
his followers are widespread.
One of those occurred today, the New York Attorney General filing a civil fraud lawsuit
against President Trump, his company, some of his family members, claiming they inflated
the value of the company.
It's going to be interesting to see where that ends up at the end of the day.
Overnight we broke a really big story and it's going to trigger I think one of our conversations
today with Congressman Ben Klein from the great state of Virginia.
He's on the appropriations committee.
He has some really great ideas about by using the power of the purse Republicans can now
begin to shrink the size of government and rein in some of the bureaucracies that don't
seem to be responsive to either Congress or the President of the United States.
We're going to have a good conversation about that.
And then in the second half of the show, we've got a great guest for you.
The first time he's ever been on the show, Troy Miller, the president and CEO of NRB,
that is the religious broadcasters trade group.
They have more than 5,000 stations around the country, more than 1,200 companies.
This is really the communications infrastructure of the Christian American movement.
Troy is a great technologist.
He came out of Silicon Valley.
He has a great man of faith.
We're going to talk a little bit about the state of cancel culture, the state of faith
in America, the state of communications and all that is going on.
I'm really looking forward to that conversation.
But before we get there, let's get started with some news.
This is a story that we broke last night that I think really has some significant implications.
It actually was hiding in plain sight.
I hate to say that, but it really was hiding in plain sight.
There was a letter known as a questions for the record.
QFR is known here in Washington because we have an alphabet soup here in Washington.
QFR, a question for the record.
Senator Chuck Grazie sent it in the data summer last month after Chris Ray had answered some
of the questions that Grazie had posited to him during a Senate Judiciary Committee in
early August.
In that meeting, in that follow-up set of questions, the questions for the record, Senator Grazie
dropped the bombshell.
It's a pretty significant acknowledgement.
What it acknowledges is that there is allegations that we believe came from the whistleblowers
because Senator Grazie has been in contact with 15 whistleblowers.
But the allegations that Senator Grazie got was that there is a very important committee.
It's called the Special Agents Advisory Committee.
It is one agent from each of the 90-plus field offices at the FBI have.
They get together and they're the sounding board for the director of the FBI to make
sure that the frontline agents in the field and the director in leadership on the seventh
floor of the FBI, that they're synchronized, that they're all queued up on the same issues
or aware of concerns.
They get ahead of concerns.
Well, in the last year, according to Senator Grazie's letter to Director Christopher Ray,
he said that he had learned, Senator Grazie had learned, that the Special Agents Advisory
Committee had provided information to the director through its reporting process, outlining
concerns among the field agents of the FBI, the frontline agents of the FBI, that the
bureau had become too politicized in its decision making, and that after that information was
included into the final report or was put into the report that goes to the director to
facilitate the communications between the Director and Advisory Committee, it was suddenly censored.
The concerns were removed.
That's a direct quote from the letter.
That means somebody in the FBI was trying to whitewash or hide or suppress a record
that would show that frontline agents of the FBI see the politicization that so much of
us have been talking about since the Russia collusion case, right?
We keep talking about that and it doesn't get the attention that a lot of people think
it deserves a pretty remarkable, fast mean, acknowledgement from Senator Grazie, a pretty
remarkable narrative.
If the whistleblowers you let allegations are true, it means that the frontline agents
are beginning to speak up.
They're seeing the politicization that you and many common sense everyday Americans are
seeing.
And so I interviewed a couple of FBI agents after this.
Kevin Brock, we have him on the show a lot.
He's a great trusted voice.
He said this is very important.
Why?
If a certain topic is raised by the committee, it usually means there has been significant
interest in this topic expressed among FBI agents.
It's reflective of what's on their minds of a large number of the field agents of the
FBI.
It is not trivial, meaning that if FBI agents are beginning to see the FBI's overly political,
that's a serious matter.
You know, agreed with that?
Jeff Tannock, former FBI agent Florida, 28 year veteran, highly decorated, one of the
more trusted FBI retirees in the country, speaks his mind really great.
He said he knows from the front lines of colleagues, people he worked with that are
still on the job that they believe the FBI's reputation is tarnished, that the politicization
is real to them and that the bungled probes like the Olympian sex abuse case, the Russia
collusion case, the Faisal eyes are worrying agents that their agency, their bureaucracy,
their institution, something they care a lot about is losing public trust.
He said, most agents recognize that they have most of the country quote pissed off at you,
pardon the French there, but that's his exact words.
And it affects every agent every day when they're out there on the job.
So beyond the alleged transmission of this report raising this concern, Danick and Kevin
Brock both saying they're hearing this also.
This is a sentiment.
This is a concern.
This is a worry.
And it seems like somebody in the leadership of FBI, if the grassy allegations were true,
we're trying to censor that, keep it from getting out to the public and becoming a reality
to all of us.
All right, folks.
A quick commercial break.
When we come back, first up, Congressman Ben Klein from Virginia.
First time we've had on the show, man and I talked to him last night, you're going to
love this interview.
He wants to talk about the very story we just mentioned about Senator Grassley.
He's also going to talk about how he has an appropriator on the House Appropriations
Committee can begin raining in way where bureaucracies like we saw in the Russia collusion case.
And then we're going to flip turn a little bit to the faith community and Troy Miller,
the president and CEO of the NRBE, the religious broadcasters group of America.
He's going to join us and talk about the state of cancel culture to state of faith, the state
of public policy.
Troy is a really brilliant thinker, thought leader in America.
You're going to really enjoy that conversation.
We'll be right right after these messages.
First up, Congressman Ben Klein.
You know, folks, we all have a heartfelt reason to support our blood pressure.

I've noticed my blood pressure much more stable.
Sure, I have to use some medicines still to keep it down, but it makes a big, big difference.

Use the promo code justnews.
Folks, I don't know if you know this, but last month, the G20 announced the plan to
impose digital currencies and digital IDs on their respective populations.
Central bank digital currencies essentially allow the government to track every one of
your purchases that you're ever going to make.
They could even allow officials to prohibit you from purchasing certain products or easily
freeze or seize part or all of your money.
In essence, they enable the government to take more control over your finances and your shopping
purchases.
Modern Americans are diversifying their assets in a physical goal with the help of my good
friends at Birch Gold Group.
If you want a physical asset held in a tax shelter retirement account, you should go
to Birch Gold too.
But learn for yourself.
Text JustNews to 98.98.98.
That's JustNews to 98.98.98.
They'll send you a free info kit on gold.
The easiest way to become a Birch Gold customer, if you have an IRA or 401K from a previous
employer, just gathering dust, Birch Gold can help you convert it into an IRA in gold.
And you don't pay a penny out of pocket.
So that's a good deal, right?
Right now, Just Go Text JustNews to 98.98.98.
Claim your free info kit on gold.
Then call them because if digital currency becomes a reality, it'll be nice to have some
gold to fall back on.
He has a chance to sit on the House Appropriations Committee where lots of big decisions will
be made if House Republicans take over after the November election.
Joining us right now from my home state of Virginia, Congressman Ben Klein, Congressman,
great to have you in the show today.
Thanks, John.
Thanks, Amanda.
Great to be with you.
I'd like to have you on, sir.
The power of the purse ring.
When you have a divided government, it's the one tool that Republicans might be able
to use against Joe Biden.
Tell us, as you heard about that last thing about the FBI, what things you might be able
to use with the power of the purse to force the FBI to start a look at some of these very
serious issues?
Well, it's been clear for many years that politics has invaded our intelligence agencies
ever since the Mueller investigation.
I was on judiciary my freshman term and definitely had a front row seat for the collapse of that
investigation under all the lies and false affidavits.
There needed to be a clearing out of our intelligence agencies at that point.
Unfortunately, we didn't get that done.
Now it falls to Congress, hopefully under a Republican-led speaker, to initiate those
investigations to make sure we figure out the truth and hopefully, using the power of the
purse, hold those accountable who have injected politics into the decision-making and hopefully
get that house cleaning that we so desperately need in our intelligence agencies.
Yeah, and Congressman, I wanted to shift to that shocking comment from that 60-minute
interview by President Biden.
He declared that the pandemic is over and out of Democrats in a lot of states used the
COVID-19 pandemic to change voting laws.
Of course, we know that it has been used to push forward things like student debt forgiveness.
So in light of the fact that according to the president, the pandemic is over, does that
basically void those emergency powers that he used to push through a lot of those agenda
items?
Well, I think it definitely calls them into question.
And what you have is a case where the president says one thing and then immediately his handlers
start walking his comments back.
And that's happened three or four times.
And you really have to ask who's running the White House because it doesn't seem to be
the president.
It seems that his handlers, his policy advisors behind the scenes, we know Susan Rice is really
leading the charge in the West Wing to dictate a lot of this policy.
They don't seem to want to let go of the reins of power.
And when Joe Biden says something that goes against what they want, they're not ready
to let go.
So while Joe Biden may insist that the pandemic is over, it's going to take his administration
coming on board with that theory to actually undo a lot of these mandates and emergency
powers that his administration has assumed over the last several years.
Congressman, the government just keeps growing and growing the last 20 years.
I've seen the most mediocre growth in the history of the United States.
When you if Republicans get control of Congress, I know you've got to commit with America coming
out soon.
Their cock is going to release.
How important is it to get under under control both the spending and the overreach of regulation
under control in the next Congress?
Yeah, we're excited about the opportunity to present to the American people this agenda
for a Republican majority.
It's going to be aggressive.
It's going to ensure that we hit the ground running when voters elect a Republican majority
in the House and the Senate.
Now the Senate's not on board with this.
This is a House priority list.
But hopefully with our swift action, we're going to be able to put pressure on the Senate
to adopt as much of it as possible as quickly as possible.
They're a little entrenched in their ways over there in the Senate.
So even if Republicans take control, we're still going to need the voice of the people
spoken through their elected House representatives and through the people expressing their desire
to their senators directly about what they want to see in terms of change in Washington,
cutting, spending, balancing the budget, making sure that we have oversight over the excesses
of this administration, the unlawful conduct at the border, the fact that we have crime
rampant in our cities, the fact that we have inflation and energy dependence now on foreign
oil, we were energy independent during the Trump administration.
Now we're back to dependence on OPEC and other nations that don't like us.
So there are a lot of hearings to be had, a lot of questions to be asked, and we're
anxious to get started.
So we hope voters definitely get to the polls and make their voices heard.
Yeah, and it won't be long before we know the result of that.
I can't believe within what 50 something days.
I wanted to ask you about the military vaccines.
I would encourage everyone to head over to just the news because one of John's reporters,
Natalia Middlestadt, was reporting on a blanket nature of religious exemptions that were denied
by the military.
But Congressman, this is something that a lot of Americans, even people who aren't in the
military, have observed as something that's very concerning.
In light of President Biden's comments about the pandemic being over, do you think that
these military vaccines for each of the branches of armed services, do you think we're going
to start to see that being lifted?
We definitely should.
We should never have gone down that road.
You have closely held religious beliefs by so many in our armed services and for them
to be shown the door or given an ultimatum between serving their country and protecting
that religious freedom.
That should never have happened.
And we must repeal these mandates and make sure that our nation is still secure because
we have not met our recruitment levels for this year for our armed services.
We have to make sure that we can recruit and retain the best and brightest in our armed
services.
And with these types of mandates, we're just not doing that.
So we have to get rid of those mandates, especially now that the president himself has said the
Commander in Chief has said that the pandemic is over.
It's time to take him at his word and get the Pentagon to remove these mandates.
No doubt.
So you've been a champion of free speech and liberty in this country, consistent and always
there's now a growing body of evidence that federal agencies, sometimes working with private
entities like social media companies, were directly involved in censoring one point of
view in America over and over again as part of the appropriations committees or anything
you can do to get federal agencies out of the censorship business and back to doing the
job they were paid for the taxpayers to do.
Absolutely.
When it comes to oversight over how your tax dollars are being spent with regard to these
federal agencies, whether it's the FEC or the FCC, any of these agencies that interact
with the telecommunications companies, the companies that are operating these social platforms,
they have to ensure that these platforms are fair and don't side with one point of view
over another.
And that's statute that some want to re-examine to see whether they should be held legally
liable for any kind of damages that are caused to individuals or businesses as a result of
this discrimination.
But that's something that the authorizing committees are going to look at in response.
We are going to make sure that the agencies are not engaging in any kind of corrupt or
illicit relationship with tech to discriminate or censor any one particular viewpoint.
That's something that the Appropriations Committee is going to make sure of, that your tax dollars
go toward ensuring a fair platform, a fair cyberspace so that everyone's point of view
is heard.
Yes, such an important part.
And it was a big ruling this week or last week I should say Texas is a social media
regulation law upheld.
Court said there's not an official amendment right to censor in America.
That's going to be an important backdrop to all this conversation.
Congressman, great to have you on the show.
Thank you for joining us today.
Thanks so much.
Great honor, sir.
Thank you.
Thanks a lot, Amanda, for joining me on this.
What a great interview.
I learned a lot.
We're going to be right back with more things just like this right after the commercial break.
All right, folks.
Welcome back from the commercial break.
Excited to have this next guest son.
He oversees, I think, one of the most important communication apparatus in America, the NRB,
the Association of All the Religious Broadcasters and Religious and Christian Communicators in
the world.
He is Troy Miller, its president and CEO.
Troy, great to have you on the show today.
John, thanks.
Thanks for having me.
Appreciate the being here.
For those who don't know enough about NRB, everybody knows what NRB is, but in general,
just describe for a second the great mission that NRB fulfills.
Sure, NRB's been around about 78 years and our core mission is to advocate for Christian
communicators, Christian broadcasters.
Folks are in the Christian communication, Christian media industry.
We work on Capitol Hill and a number of other places to keep the avenues open so Christians
could be in the marketplace of ideas.
They could be in the culture talking about what they do.
All the way from Christian broadcasters to pastors to folks who write books.
We do that.
And then another big thing we do is we provide networking opportunities for Christians to
get together, work on like-minded projects.
It's the old, and the Bible says, iron sharpens iron.
And so we bring folks together.
We have an annual conference every year.
Next year we'll be in Orlando in May, and it's the largest conference of Christian communicators.
So it's just great to work together.
It is an amazing force.
I've been a journalist 35 years and NRB has done so much good in the country.
And really when you think of the Christian communicating infrastructure, it is larger,
more sophisticated, and more influential today than at any point it has embraced all the different
mediums and delivers.
In fact, really is at the center point of a lot of the revival of American radio, right?
Oh, yeah, correct.
I think you're right.
Christian radio reaches some 70 million listeners across the country daily.
People that dial in for Christian music, for Christian teaching, they get in.
The other thing that people don't know about Christian radio in general, but Christian
radio in particular, Christian radio is a vital part of local communities.
Christian radio, the first spokes that are helping food banks are the first folks that
are in there when disasters strike in communities.
They bring in faith-based folks to help when tragedies hit for counseling and just a number
of things that Christian radio does beyond just the broadcast.
And I think that's really important.
That's kind of a backbone of where we are today.
Faith has always been a backbone of charity, and Christian charity has always been on the
front lines.
Yeah, no, it really has.
And it shows the power of just what private faith can do.
It can do as much and sometimes more than government can ever do because of the extraordinary
people in the Christian movement.
Troy, a couple of weeks now, it's been almost three weeks, hard to believe, the famous Red
Wall speech, President Biden's speech.
A lot of people took that as an attack on Magonation or Donald Trump supporters.
But really, when you go into the words, the sentence, the phraseology, it really was an
attack on Christian and Judeo values.
How concerning was that speech to you, to NRB, to the members of NRB?
You know, very concerning.
You look at a president that ran on a platform that he was going to bring unity to the nation.
He was going to bring people together.
And then he gets up and he makes one of probably one of the most divisive speeches that's ever
been made by a president.
And he directly calls out, in our opinion, my opinion, people of faith.
When he talked about the country going backwards, the areas that he talked about, going back
words in the family, he was talking about the whole LGBTQ side.
He talked about the pro-life movement, the recent Dobbs case.
You know, he called that going backwards.
He talked about going backwards in gender identity.
And that was really targeted to Christians because those are values that Christians bring
to the conservative movement.
They're not economic conservatives.
They're not social conservatives.
They're not social conservatives.
They're not social conservatives.
They're not economic conservatives.
They're not social conservatives.
Those are moral values that the jail, the Christian, the belief spring.
And so the president's calling out this huge part of America.
You know, you know, research tells us that some 60% of Americans still believe in God
and believe that faith is important in this country.
78% of people say faith is still part of the foundation of this country.
And so whether he was calling out as Trump voters, MAGA voters or not, he was calling
out a large group of this country and say, you're taking the country backwards and you're
the most dangerous thing to democracy.
Yeah, there's a great line in there.
I want to say great.
I mean, great in the sense that it summarizes the true attack, the broad side he put on
faith in their world, meaning due to the Christian's world.
There's no right to choose, no right to privacy, no right to contraception, no right to marry
who you love.
So if you're a pro-marriage, a pro-life, you are a threat to the American experience according
to our current president.
How have Christians responded to this attack to this speech in the two and a half weeks
since then?
You know, I think the Christian response for the most part has been shock and surprise.
I think the speech woke a lot of people up.
I think it brought the issue to the forefront.
I think a lot of folks thought that there was a lot of hyperbole, a lot of over-the-top
of this, but the president called them out directly.
It came from the top, from the president.
And so I think a lot of Christians have said, hey, it's time for us not to be silent
anymore.
It's time for us to get involved, to be active and to do our civic duty so that we can continue
to do what we call our Christian duty.
We talked about it before.
Christians just want to do their Christian duty in society.
They want to be the charitable artist society.
They want to actually help people in, excuse me.
And yet we have a president that's saying you're taking the country backwards.
And that, I think that really put a lot of people on notice.
Yeah, it sure did.
There's no doubt about it.
And you can see it in the polling too, the reaction by a vast majority of Americans was,
this is not what we want our president to be saying and standing for.
NRB has always been an organization that supported full engagement in our constitutional republic
in elections, but I've been watching over the last year.
You guys have put a big emphasis on it.
It's not enough just to go and vote anymore in election day, getting to city council meetings,
to school board meetings, to the local pregnancy centers, to their churches.
That is also a clarion call of faith.
And it's so much more important now as the left has captured a lot of these institutions.
Do you think Christians and Christian communicators have responded and are getting down to that
level of civic engagement?
Absolutely.
If you just look at some of the organizations that are active across the country today,
Christian organizations, there's been a big homeschool movement, school choice movement.
The backbone of that is by the, you know, a lot of the homeschool movement that's been
around for a long time.
It's enabled a lot of Christians to get involved in my own community in Tennessee.
They've totally flipped the school board on local elections with folks that want to get
involved.
And we're seeing that all across the country.
It's a sort of, we're not going to take it anymore.
And you know, we want these institutions to work for us and not against us.
So Christians have been getting involved in, in, as you said, school boards.
They've been involved in county commissions and city councils.
So it's a real bottoms up grassroots movement that I think you're going to see keep sweeping
across the country.
Yeah.
And what's really interesting about it is a growing alliance between traditional Christian
conservatives, evangelicals, and Latinos, Hispanics in America.
And also I can tell that the left is panicked by that, because the Soros family, one of
his institutions is out buying 18 of the more famous Spanish language radio stations in
America.
There is a battle for the heart and soul of Hispanic America right now.
Tell us about the transformation that's going on and how NRB is at the middle of it.
Yeah, you know, there, I think there's a real transformation or maybe just a real kind of
awareness in the Spanish community.
Spanish community has always been a deep community of faith.
It's been a deep community of family.
In some senses, they hold family together better than some of the other Western, you
know, ethnicities in there.
And, and so they're looking at the attacks here and they see that not just as a attack
on white conservatives.
They see that as a pack on their family, family value.
So NRB in itself in the last two years that are in there, we can mention we've had a very
large Spanish group that's pulled up.
So we have a Spanish group will have one next year that's going to meet early and they're
going to have a whole set of sessions that look at what it means for the Spanish community.
We've not only involved in faith, but to be involved in the civic side of what goes on
in America.
So we're just seeing that continue to grow.
Yes, that's an important tectonic shifting of the political plates beneath our country
right now.
Before we wrap up, Trey, what are the most important issues right now for the NRB and
its extraordinary group of communicators?
What are the legislative policy and political issues that are on the top of the priority
list for NRB?
Well, a number of things for watching very closely, what's going to go on with the social
media companies that continue to, you know, cancel and throttle back the Christian voice.
We saw the number of congressmen ask Google to change their algorithms so that credit
basis, then C centers wouldn't come to the top.
So that kind of cooperation amongst the government and amongst these private groups to really
take away the fundamental rights of free speech and free exercise.
That's a big issue that we're really watching.
I think that's one of the top issues our folks are concerned with today and where these government
institutions are going to go to continue to try to silence what we call the Christian
worldview.
Yeah, so important that we stand top of those issues because Annie, inattention, all of
a sudden progress is made and people say, hey, how did that happen?
What did that happen?
No, a moment of the eye off the ball as all it takes these days.
Troy, for people who want to get involved or follow NRB, you've got an incredible television
network, NRB TV.
Tell folks how they can stay connected to all the different ways that NRB provides public
service.
Yeah, a couple of things.
You can go to NRB.org.
We have a number of newsletters that we put out.
We have a lot of information there that's on NRB.org.
We have a number of our folks.
We have an NRB convention.
If you want to get involved in that, NRBconvention.org, to get involved at, you can sign up for the
newsletters there.
And we also have a list of a lot of our broadcasters and members in our BTVB and one.
Salem Bot Radio, just a number of folks out there that you can get connected to.
So it's all at NRB.org.
Yeah, such a remarkable organization.
And I've always fun to see it in action.
I know they're excited to have you at the helm of the agency now.
Really, really great.
Troy, it's been an honor.
We're going to get you on more often because these issues are so important.
You are a mover and shaker and one of the most important communication apparatus of
the world.
So great honor to have you on today.
Thanks, John.
Thanks for all you do and keep up all the good work getting the truth out here to the
folks in this country.
We're going to try real hard.
So thanks, Troy.
Great time with you today.
All right, folks.
We're going to take a quick commercial break when we come back.
We'll wrap things up for the day.
All right, folks, I'd wrap up another edition of John Solomon reports.
Thanks for joining us today.
A special thank you to Congressman Ben Klein, who happens to be the Congressman in the
district where I have my cabin up in the Shenandoah Mountain.
So I've gotten to know him.
Really I've got some very thoughtful comments, some solution-based ideas of how to use the
power of the purse to begin raining in the out of control central government and so many
people see in America.
And then Troy Miller, joining us from the NRB, the Religious Broadcasters Association,
really two very thoughtful guests with a lot of solutions, a lot of ideas to people on
the front lines of the great struggle for the American soul that's at stake here in the
next couple of elections.
We're going to wrap up for the day here.
Before we do that, though, I want to mention one of our great partners.
You here, Philip Patrick, on our show all the time, I think he's given us some of the
